components.metaDescription: The HEAL Platform shares data from the NIH HEAL Initiative® with the community of researchers, healthcare providers, community leaders, policy makers, and other stakeholders.

introduction.heading: Data Commons
introduction.text: The HEAL QA Data Commons supports the management, analysis and sharing of data for the research community.

systemUse.systemUseTitle: HEAL Data Platform Data Use Agreement
systemUseText: The HEAL Data Platform provides access to data from HEAL-funded and related studies. The Platform is funded by and operated on behalf of the NIH HEAL InitiativeÂ®. Users of the Platform must agree to abide by the following terms of use:

1. Access to all data is granted and managed by the host repository and may involve an application and approval process and/or be subject to a repository-specific Data Use Agreement (DUA) or additional terms and conditions. Users who obtain data through the HEAL Platform must abide by these at all times.
2. Any attempt to re-identify or contact individual study participants for any reason, including for obtaining or linking additional information for analytic purposes, is strictly forbidden.

3. Redistribution of data by posting them on a website or submitting them to a data or code repository is forbidden. Users wishing to share their work so that others may reproduce their results should post their code only to a code repository (e.g., GitHub) and include instructions for accessing or requesting access to the data directly from the HEAL Data Platform, making sure to include information on the version of the data product used in the analysis.
4. Use of data in publications or presentations must acknowledge the source of the data by providing the following two citations:
a. The recommended citation for study records on the HEAL Data Platform is: Author Names (Year). Study Title [version number]. HEAL Data Platform. Study Record. [DOI].
b. In addition, you must cite the corresponding data resource on the host repository using their suggested citation format.

5. You are strongly encouraged to notify the HEAL Initiative (HEALquestion@od.nih.gov) once a paper using the data has been accepted for publication, so that it may be added to the list of publications that have used the data.

6. All data are provided as-is and without any assurances either explicit or implied. Neither the HEAL Data Platform nor the host data repository assumes any responsibility for results obtained from the data.
7. Your authorization credentials (e.g., your username and password or API key) are for your use only and must not be shared with others for any purpose.
8. The system must be used lawfully and in accordance with all applicable Federal, State, Local and Institutional regulations or policies.
By clicking Accept below, I hereby certify that:

a. I have read and understand all of the terms and conditions above and agree to abide by them, as well as any other terms and conditions that may apply to specific datasets as described by the host repository or in a separate, written Data Use Agreement (DUA).

b. I understand that unless explicitly prohibited by these terms and conditions, I may make these data available to individuals working directly under my supervision, and if I do it is my responsibility to make sure that they adhere to these terms and conditions at all times.
c. I understand that failure to comply with these terms and conditions may result in immediate termination of access privileges by the HEAL Data Platform and the host repository.

items.name: Discovery
items.tooltip: Use free-text search and tags to find studies, discover datasets, and export selected data files to an analysis workspace.

items.name: Workspace
items.tooltip: Gen3 workspaces are secure cloud environments where users can analyze data from one or more data resources.

items.name: Example Analysis
items.tooltip: Learn how to use Jupyter Notebooks to explore and visualize data available on the HEAL platform by running a static tutorial notebook, or use one of these examples as a launching point for your own custom analysis.

items.name: Profile
items.tooltip: Create API keys for programmatic data access, and review your authorization privileges to datasets and services.

login.title: HEAL QA Data Commons
login.subTitle: Explore, Analyze, and Share Data
login.text: This website supports the discovery, analysis and sharing of data and aims to support the accelerated discovery and development of therapies, diagnostic tests, and other technologies.
login.contact: If you have any questions about access or the registration process, please contact

studyPreviewField.name: Summary
studyPreviewField.valueIfNotAvailable: No summary has been provided for this study.

fields.name: Summary
fields.valueIfNotAvailable: No summary has been provided for this study.

resourceBrowser.title: Static HEAL Tutorial Notebooks
resourceBrowser.description: The Jupyter notebooks contained in this notebook viewer pull data from various sources to generate and output useful tables, charts, graphs, and models. Each notebook is static, meaning the data being used by the notebooks is not updated in real time. These notebooks are also available in the Gen3 Tutorials Workspace. Please note these notebooks are meant for illustrative purposes only, and are not meant to portray peer-reviewed research.

resources.title: BACPAC Synthetic Data Analysis
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used synthetic data of the BACPAC study as an example to demonstrate how to navigate datasets within the workspace in HEAL and conduct data analysis using Python libraries.

resources.title: JCOIN Tracking Opioid Stigma
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the JCOIN-MAARC (Justice Community Opioid Innovation Network - Methodology and Advanced Analytics Resource Center) Survey Core Survey Project 1/4 to track stigma related to Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) and public attitudes towards persons with OUD as well as how treatment of/for persons with OUD may impact the effect of OUD interventions.

resources.title: Opioid Prevalence And Overdoses
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the CDC WONDER, DEA ARCOS, and PDAPS datasets to demonstate how multiple datasets may be utilized within the workspace in HEAL.

resources.title: Opioid Overdose Trajectories
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the CDC WONDER dataset to explore opioid overdose death rate trajectories in the United States.

resources.title: Opioid Environment Toolkit And OEPS R
resources.description: In this R notebook, we used the Opioid Environment Policy Scan (OEPS) and the Opioid Environment Toolkit to characterize the multi-dimensional risk environment impacting opioid use.

resources.title: JCOIN MOUD Accessibility Analysis
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the data from the OEPS database to analyze the Medication for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) providers accessibility at state and county level across the United States

resources.title: Changes In Opioid Treatment Policy During COVID-19
resources.description: In this notebook we used data from NIDA-PDAPS and CDC WONDER mortality data to visualize the relationship between statewide changes in opioid treatment policy and opioid overdose mortality rates in 2020.

resources.title: Rates Of Opioid Overdose Deaths And COVID-19 In 2020
resources.description: In this notebook we examine correlations between statewide rates of opioid overdose deaths and COVID-19 cases and deaths.

resources.title: Monitoring The Future: 12th Grader Opiate Use - Part 1
resources.description: In this notebook we use a variety of machine learning methods to analyze patterns in 12th grader opiate use as reported in the Monitoring The Future survey results from 2019.

resources.title: Monitoring The Future: 12th Grader Opiate Use - Part 2
resources.description: In this notebook we use a variety of machine learning methods to analyze patterns in 12th grader opiate use as reported in the Monitoring The Future survey results from 2012 through 2021.

studyRegistrationConfig.studyRegistrationFormDisclaimerField: Information provided on this page will be used for correspondence regarding your request and may be shared with the NIH and/or the HEAL Data Stewards
studyRegistrationConfig.dataDictionarySubmissionDisclaimerField: All submitted data dictionaries will be available to public.

workspaceRegistrationConfig.workspaceInfoMessage: The HEAL workspace provides a standardized computational environment for accessing and analyzing data from HEAL studies. Please fill out this form to request access to the workspace and start computing!
